questions.text:
A 4 year old sick child with spO2 level of 60 percent, inspiratory stridor, muffled voice with X-Ray Neck lateral view image.
Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
It is an acute inflammatory condition confined to supra-glottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds and arytenoids. There is marked oedema of these structures which may obstruct the airway.

AETIOLOGY

It is a serious condition and affects children of 2-7 years of age but can also affect adults.

H. influenzae B is the most common organism responsible for this condition in children.

CLINICAL FEATURES

  1. Onset of symptoms is abrupt with rapid
  2. Sore throat and dysphagia are the common presenting symptoms in adults.
  3. Dyspnoea and stridor are the common presenting symptoms in children. They are rapidly progressive and may prove fatal unless relieved.
  4. Fever may go up to 40°C. It is due to patient's condition may rapidly deteriorate.

EXAMINATION

  1. Depressing the tongue with a tongue depressor may show red and swollen epiglottis. Indirect laryngoscopy may show oedema and congestion of supraglottic structure. This examination is avoided for fear of precipitating complete obstruction. It is better done in operation theatre where facilities for intubation are available.
  2. Lateral soft tissue X-ray of neck may show swollen epi-glottis (thumb sign).

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, AND Throat by PL Dhingra, Pg.338, 339

questions.text:
A 23 year old young man member of a music band, who plays saxophone for the last 10 years. The band has been doing many popular concerts. He has developed a neck swelling on the left side of the larynx. X ray of Neck is shown in the picture

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of laryngocele

Saccule is a mucosal out pouching from the ventricle of larynx, the potential space between true and false vocal cords (TVC & FVC: image 1).

Laryngocele is an abnormally dilated saccule (Image 2).

This is more commonly seen in persons who play wind based instruments like trumpets, saxophones etc. The presentation is an air filled lateral neck swelling which on pressing gives the sound of air leakage ( Bryce's sign). X-ray soft tissue neck with valsalva will show an air filled neck swelling on the side of larynx.

  1. Thyroglossal cyst is a midline swelling formed due to non-obliteration of thyroglossal tract.
  2. Branchial Cyst is formed due to non-obliteration of second branchial cleft. It presents as lateral neck swelling in childhood or early adulthood with increase in size following an episode of upper respiratory infection.

D. Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst of sublingual glands which presents as a bluish translucent swelling in floor of mouth.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no 355, 333; Scott Brown's Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Volume 3, Page number - 1008

questions.text: A singer has undergone thyroid surgery 1 month back. Her recovery has been satisfactory except that she is unable to sing higher notes now. What is the possible nerve injury which could have happened during thyroid surgery of the patient?
questions.solution:
Paralysis of superior laryngeal nerve causes paralysis of cricothyroid muscle and ipsilateral anaesthesia of the larynx above the vocal cord.

Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cord which is supplied by external branch of SLN. Paralysis of this muscle leads to bowing down of vocal cords and hence loss of pitch of voice with decreased ability to sing.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 350

questions.text:
A patient of T3N0M0 carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy. He has permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. He is using the device given in picture for vocal rehabilitation

What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Electrolarynx or artificial larynx

  • Battery operated, hand held portable device.
  • Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth and palate.
  • Used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech

Blom singer prosthesis and panje's prosthesis are tracheo-oesophageal speech devices.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no 365

questions.text: A 33 year old female patient has suddenly developed aphonia. Her laryngeal endoscopy picture shows immobile cords as shown in the picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Both the vocal cords are lying immobile in intermediate or cadaveric position. There is no adduction.

So the diagnosis is bilateral adductor palsy.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 349

questions.text: The patient has enlarged tonsils and is unable to swallow. The patient is also complaining of ear pain. Which nerve is the Likely a source of ear pain?
questions.solution: Jacobson's nerve, also known as the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, can cause referred pain to the ear. The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the tonsils and tonsillar fossa, so any irritation or pain in these areas can be referred to the ear along the Jacobson's nerve.

questions.text: A 17 year old male patient presented to ENT OPD with the history of nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding. The nasal endoscopy picture shows a mass in the choana as given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare highly vascular tumor within the posterior nasal cavity found almost exclusively in adolescent boys. The most common presentation is an adolescent male with chronic unilateral nasal obstruction. Also, painless, unprovoked epistaxis is common. Other presenting complaints consist of headache and rhinorrhea, and when the mass is large and invasive, proptosis, visual disturbance, cranial nerve palsy. On physical exam, a mass is generally visible within the nasal cavity.

choices.text: It is normal to have mild bleeding in post-operative period, so patient can be reassured and sent home
Admission and Immediate Re-exploration in operation theatre

questions.text: A 17 years old male patient underwent tonsillectomy on Monday. His post operative period was uneventful. He was discharged on next day. On Sunday morning, he has presented in the Emergency Department of hospital with the complaint of mild bleeding from oral cavity. What is the best further management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of secondary hemorrhage.

  1. Secondary hemorrhage is seen after 5th day of tonsillectomy. It is due to infection of tonsillar fossa and is managed with I/V antibiotics.
  2. Reactionary hemorrhage is seen after 24 hours of tonsillectomy. It is due to slippage of ligature and it should be immediately re-explored under GA.
  3. Primary Haemorrhage is during surgery

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Pg. no. 506

questions.text: A 52 year adult patient presenting with right sided hearing loss has been subjected to audiological investigations and was found to have a type B tympanogram. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a suspected case of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma(NPC).

Type B tympanogram is suggestive of glue ear(serous otitis media).

The unilateral serous otitis media(presenting as conductive hearing loss) in an adult patient should always arise the suspicion of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hence, nasopharyngoscopy should be done and biopsy of any suspicious area should be taken.

Nasopharyngeal cancer is the occult hidden primary. Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presentation of NPC.

Myringotomy and grommet insertion will be done for glue ear at a later date when NPC is ruled out.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Pg. no. 297

questions.text: A 27 year healthy adult has presented with sudden onset throat pain and odynophagia. The Oropharyngeal picture is given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Quiencke's disease is sudden idiopathic isolated angioedema of uvula. It is due to food allergy or idiopathic. Intravenous steroids are given to manage it

In quinsy(peritonsillar abscess), tonsil is pushed medially and uvula is deviated to the other side.

Thorwaldt's disease is infection of the bursa of nasopharynx. Presents as a nasal obstruction or persistant post nasal drip.

Vincent angina - Membrane, which usually forms over one tonsil, can be easily removed revealing an irregular ulcer on the tonsil. Throat swab will show both the organisms typical of disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Pg. no. 306, 288, 311

questions.text: Turbinate that articulates with maxilla is
questions.solution:
Inferior turbinate articulates with the maxilla.

Superior and middle turbinates are parts of ethmoid bone.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no 159

questions.text: A boxer has been hit on face by fellow player. He has developed nasal blockage on both sides and there is swelling around the nose. What is the further treatment?
questions.solution:
This is a case of septal hematoma.

Bilateral nasal obstruction is the most common presenting symptom.

Treatment:

  • Immediate aspiration or incision and drainage.
  • Followed by bilateral nasal packing to prevent reaccumulation.
  • Systemic antibiotics - to prevent formation of septal abscess.

Complications -

  • If not drained, may organize into fibrous tissue leading to a permanently thickened septum.
  • Septal abscess
  • Saddle nose deformity

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 173, 174

Reference: Scott Brown's Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Volume 1, Page - 434

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic bacterial sinusitis presents to the emergency department with a very severe headache. Physical examination demonstrates high fever and chills, exophthalmos, papilledema, and nerve palsies of the VI and III cranial nerves on one side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a history of chronic bacterial sinusitis, headache, exophthalmos, papilledema and VI and III nerve palsies indicates possible cavernous sinus thrombosis.

CECT helps establish the diagnosis and differentiate it from orbital cellulitis which should be ruled out in this scenario.

Treatment of cavernous sinus thrombosis - IV antibiotics

Identify and clear the focus of infection.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 233, 234

questions.text: 16 year old patient presents with pain over the cheek. Patient also complains of nasal discharge and nasal blockage. Examination reveals oedema of lower eyelids and purulent discharge in middle meatus. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected?
questions.solution:
This is a case of maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge in middle meatus is pathognomic of maxillary sinusitis.

Other symptoms include constitutional symptoms, headache, postnasal drip, pain - over the cheek, upper jaw, but may be referred to the gums or teeth.

Lower eyelid edema and mucosal edema can also be seen.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 223, 224

questions.text: Which of the following sinus is not visible on Water's View?
questions.solution:
All sinuses can be seen in Water's view except ethmoid sinus.

Ethmoid sinus is seen in Caldwell view.

Water's view - (occipitomental view or nose-chin position).

Structures seen are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best).
  • Frontal sinuses.
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth).
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Nasal bone.
  • Frontal process of maxilla.
  • Superior orbital fissure.
  • Intratemporal fossa

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 509-511

questions.text: A patient of suspected sinusitis has undergone CT scan of paranasal sinuses coronal cuts 5mm. The CT scan shows an unusual cell marked with arrow. What is the name of this cell?
questions.solution:
Concha bullosa means pneumatized middle turbinate. It is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells. It drains into frontal recess directly or through agger nasi cells.

CONCHA BULLOSA

Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell.

Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest and most consistent anterior ethmoid air cell.

Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid air cells and lies in close relation to optic nerve.

Reference: Scott Brown's Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Volume 1, Page - 973

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 159, 219

questions.text: A patient presents to her GP with recurrent nosebleeds and also complains of facial fullness and facial pain. Over the past 2 months she has developed progressive shortness of breath and on one occasion she coughed up some blood. What would be the most appropriate test to perform?
questions.solution:
The mostly likely diagnosis in this case is Wegeners granulamotosis. Sinusitis is the commonest ENT manifestation of this auto immune disorder. Septal perforation (bony and cartilaginous), saddle nose deformity with epistaxis is commonly seen. The multi-system involvement leads to pulmonary symptoms. The biopsy from the nose reveals necrotising vasculitis in this case. ANCA(Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) testing is further helpful for the diagnosis.

Reference: Scott Brown's Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Volume 1, Page - 133

questions.text: A young female presented to the OPD because her friends always complained of a foul smell emanating from her. On examination, wide roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation is seen. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is most likely a case of Atrophic rhinitis (Ozaena).

  • It is progressive atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinates → wide roomy nasal cavity.
  • Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty.
  • There is merciful anosmia (patient is unaware of the fowl smell) due to sensory nerve fibre degeneration.
  • Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or greyish black dry crusts → Attempts to remove them may cause epistaxis.
  • Klebsiella ozaenae is possible aetiology

Option b - Rhinosporidiosis presents as a polypoid nasal mass

Option c - Rhinoscleroma - has atrophic, granulomatous and cicatricial stages.

Option d - Rhinitis sicca - is a form of chronic rhinitis presenting with crusts on anterior nasal septum. Removal of crusts causes ulceration and epistaxis.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 178, 179

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal stuffiness and nasal obstruction. On nasal endoscopic examination, he has been found to have bilateral nasal polypi. He also mentions episodes of wheezing and difficulty in breathing which are resolved by the use of an inhaler. Which of the following drugs would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of bronchial asthma (episodes of wheezing resolved by inhaler usage) has presented with a nasal polyp now.

Aspirin should be avoided in this patient as he may be intolerant to it.

Samter's triad is classically described as -

  • Nasal polypi (Ethmoidal)
  • Asthma (Intrinsic)
  • Aspirin intolerance (NSAIDs)

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 201

choices.text: Next day removal of foreign body in elective operation theatre

questions.text: Sunil, 7 year old child has presented at midnight to emergency with the history of putting a disc battery of his father's wrist watch in his nose few hours back. What would be the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Disc batteries contain alkali - sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide and mercury which leaks through them to cause injury. It is observed that a disc battery causes damage to mucosa in 1 hour.

Hence disc battery should be urgently removed from the nose.

Xylometazoline nasal drops decongest the nose and are used in management of rhinosinusitis.

Anterior nasal packing is used in management of epistaxis.

Next day removal of foreign body is not suggestive for disc batteries.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no - 409

questions.text: Patient has the complaint of right sided hearing loss and left ear hearing is normal. Tuning fork tests show that Rinne is Negative on right side and positive on left side. Weber test is lateralised towards right ear. Absolute bone conduction(ABC) test is normal both sides. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
RINNE TEST:

It is a comparison of air conduction and bone conduction

WEBER TEST:

Place the tuning fork at centre of the head and ask the patient where the sound is heard.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 27.

questions.text: A young man has right side hearing loss following an accident. On otoscopic examination, right tympanic membrane was normal. Pure tone audiogram shows conductive hearing loss of 54 dB in the right ear. Which of the following will be the likely tympanometry finding?
questions.solution:
• Conductive hearing loss of 54 dB implies that hearing loss is due to ossicular chain disruption with an intact TM. Type Ad tympanogram is seen in such cases.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 29.

questions.text: A 75 year-old diabetic patient presents with severe pain in the ear and facial palsy. Examination reveals granulation tissue in external auditory canal and blood stained ear discharge. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MALIGNANT OTITIS EXTERNA:

  • It is infection of the underlying bone of EAC.
  • It is also called as skull base osteomyelitis.
  • It is a life-threatening infection, therefore called malignant otitis externa.
  • It is seen in elderly diabetic patients (60-70 years).

It is caused by Pseudomonas

Clinical Picture

Old diabetic patient with severe ear ache, blood stained Ear discharge, facial paralysis ± 9, 10, 11,12 paralysis via skull base.

Examination by otoscopy

GRANULATIONS in EAC, this leads to blood-stained ear discharge.

  • Facial nerve is the most commonly involved Nerve.

Investigation:

  1. Technetium (technetium) bone scan- for diagnosis*
  2. CT scan. (For extent of disease)

Treatment

Drug of Choice → 3rd Gen Cephalosporin(+ Aminoglycoside)

How to assess the response to treatment - Gallium Bone scan, ESR, C-Reactive protein and Clinical Examination.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 61.

choices.text: Adenoid Hypertrophy & Otitis media with effusion
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma & Otitis media with effusion

questions.text: A seven year old child patient has mild hearing loss along with nasal obstruction, crowding of upper teeth and dull voice. The otoscopy examination finding is given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
GLUE EAR (OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION-OME)

It is most common cause of hearing loss.

  • Glue ear is also called SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA or SECRETORY OTITIS MEDIA. (SOM)
  • Its new name is OME (OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION).
  • It is collection of sterile thick glue-like fluid in middle ear.
  • Basic aetiology of glue ear is ET blockage.
  • Most common age is school age children.

AETIOLOGY :

  1. Adenoid hypertrophy in Children → mostly B/L
  2. NPC in Adult → mostly UIL

Clinical Picture :

School age child complaining of

  • Heaviness in the ear (it is not painful disease).
  • Conductive hearing loss (CHL). (10 to 40dB)
  • Poor school performance.

+/- Adenoid face

Examination

  1. Glue like fluid behind TM.
  2. Air bubbles trapped within glue.
  3. Retracted tympanic membrane.
  4. Very rarely bluish tympanic membrane.

Treatment : Surgery

  • Myringotomy in (Anteroinferior quadrant) + Grommet insertion (also called as middle ear ventilation tube) + Adenoidectomy.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Chapter name: Disorders of Middle Ear, Page number: 75

questions.text: A 43 year old male patient is suffering from recurrent episodes of vertigo, hearing loss and tinnitus for last 3 years. The episode has nausea and vomiting along with vertigo. The episode settles in few hours only. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MENIERES DISEASE-ENDOLYMPHATIC HYDROPS:

  • In Meniere's disease, there is a rise in endolymph volume due to poor absorption by endolymphatic sac.

It is mostly unilateral disease. →I/L Migraine

  • Slightly more common in males. 3rd to 4th decade
  • Etiology is unknown.
  • It is an episodic disease. I/L Migraine

During Episode:

  • Episode has 3 features
    1. Tinnitus - it is the first symptom.
    2. Vertigo (With nausea, vomiting)
    3. Hearing loss.

+/- Fullness in ear

In between episodes

  1. Tinnitus may persist.
  2. Patient hears loud sounds as more loud. This is called Recruitment phenomenon
  3. Patients can get vertigo on hearing loud sounds. This is called Tullio's phenomenon
  4. Patient has a dislike for noisy areas.
  5. Patients hear the same sound in 2 frequencies. This is called Diplacusis

FEW YEARS LATER

Cochlear damage starts due to high endolymphatic pressure. (Glaucoma of ear).

This leads to hearing loss in between episodes also. This will lead to Fluctuating hearing loss Meniere's disease causes low Frequency SNHL in early stages.

Investigations

  1. PTA (pure tone audiometry) - unilateral SNHL (Low frequencies SNHL in early stages). This will lead to a rising audiogram.
  2. RECRUITMENT PHENOMENON is positive.
  3. SHORT INCREMENT SENSITIVITY INDEX (SISI)
  4. Electrocochleography(ECOCHG) - SP:AP Ratio>30% (used for diagnostic workup of MENIERES disease.)

TREATMENT:

  1. During episode - anti vertigo medications. Eg - prochlorperazine, cinnarizine.
  2. In between episode - Acetazolamide (diuretic)

If episodes of vertigo become more frequent and disabling Further treatment options Think of 2 scenarios.

  1. Residual hearing is present-
    1. VESTIBULAR NEURECTOMY - Transect the vestibular branch of 8th nerve to a control vertigo symptoms.
    2. MENIET DEVICE - Home based therapy: Everyday It is Intermittent low pressure pulse therapy for inner ear.
    3. ENDOLYMPHATIC SAC DECOMPRESSION SURGERY
  2. If no residual hearing is there -
    1. Transtympanic Gentamycin Injection
    2. Surgical Labyrinthectomy.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 52, 119.
